Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Phylogenetic relationships of Mid-Late Miocene hominoids: implications for understanding great ape and human evolution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Great apes, humans, and their ancestors have been the subject of substantial research, but there is much more to be learned about their shared evolutionary history leading up to the advent of the hominin lineage and upright walking. This project aims to more accurately determine relationships among fossil and living apes, and to use this information to better understand the evolution of characteristic ape and human locomotor behaviors, including those of our recent fossil ancestors. The project has broader impacts that include the generation of a large anatomical dataset that will be made freely accessible for future use, and the promotion of diversity in biological anthropology by the co-PI, a female graduate student and active member of several organizations aimed at engaging young girls in STEM fields.

The primary objective of this study is to generate a robust phylogeny of stem and crown Hominidae to be used as a basis for testing competing phylogenetic hypotheses, and exploring questions about the polarity, geography, and evolutionary timing of the locomotor and positional behaviors characterizing great apes and humans using ancestral state reconstruction. Characters will be sampled from the skull and postcranium, with particular emphasis on the inclusion of novel quantitative and polymorphic characters from the postcranial skeleton. Parsimony and Bayesian methods will be used to infer phylogeny and to measure the relative support for competing phylogenetic hypotheses. This project represents the most comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of Mid-Late Miocene hominoids carried out to date and will provide a necessary foundation for future research in early hominin and ape systematics and paleobiology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The living great apes, humans, and their fossil relatives (hominids) are among the most intensively studied mammals, yet many aspects of their shared evolutionary history are not well understood. In particular, the evolutionary relationships of many fossil species on the hominid family tree are largely unknown or remain highly contentious, despite many recent fossil discoveries. Evolutionary, or phylogenetic, relationships provide the necessary context to frame other questions asked by paleoanthropologists, such as those related to the order and timing of appearance of specific traits (e.g. suspensory locomotion) and the direction of migration events within and between continents.

This project represents the most comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of Mid-Late Miocene (~16-5 million years ago) hominids carried out to date, and aims to more accurately infer evolutionary relationships of great apes and to use this information to gain a clearer understanding of great ape and human evolution. A matrix sampling informative qualitative and quantitative anatomical features from the entire skeleton was compiled for fossil great ape species, including the earliest potential hominins Sahelanthropus, Orrorin, and Ardipithecus. Preliminary results, based on a sample of 228 features (90 qualitative and 138 quantitative) scored separately for males and females of 31 extant and fossil hominoid species found support for the hominin status of Ardipithecus, Orrorin, and Sahelanthropus. Most Eurasian fossil apes are inferred to be stem-hominids (not more closely related to any of the living great apes), except for Ouranopithecus, Khoratpithecus, and Sivapithecus, which are part of the living great ape group. These results are potentially very significant, as numerous publications have instead argued that 1) Ardipithecus and Sahelanthropus, in particular, might be apes rather than early hominins, and 2) that many Eurasian apes are close relatives of living great apes. Thus, the results here add valuable information and will almost certainly influence these ongoing debates. Forthcoming analyses will address questions that are of key interest to paleoanthropologists, including what locomotor mode preceded upright walking and the geographic dispersal patterns of fossil and living apes across Eurasia and Africa. 

In addition to its intellectual merits and scientific impact, this project provided broader impacts in terms of substantial research, project management, and mentorship training to the co-PI. As part of this project the PIs encouraged and employed the participation of six undergraduate and high school students, many of whom are from underrepresented groups in STEM fields, providing training in paleoanthropological methods and support for development of independent projects. Some of these students will likely become co-authors on eventual conference presentations and publications. Additionally, the co-PI used this project to directly engage the public in scientific discourse, especially related to evolutionary biology and human and ape evolution, as a visiting scientist in the Sackler Lab at the American Museum of Natural History. The public was also engaged in 2017 through media coverage of the high profile publication of the most complete fossil ape cranium known (Nyanzapithecus alesi; see Nengo et al., 2017), which included both the PI and co-PI as authors and used some of the data and methods from the current project as a major portion of that paper.
